Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Long Term Spatiotemporal Control to Investigate Dynamics in Xenopus Laevis Embryonic Development

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative research project will develop a system for investigating embryonic development. Specifically the team will develop a system for controlling the chemical environment of nearly microscopic (~1/20th of an inch) samples of embryonic tissues, such as from the African clawed frog, Xenopus laevis, frequently used by biologists. By controlling the region of the tissue that is exposed to different chemicals, and the time for which it is exposed, the research team can gain unprecedented insight into the embryonic development process. Our system will employ sophisticated independent control of five inlet-ports supplying three different fluidic streams. This system will have a wide range of applications for manipulation of the complex chemical environment of engineered tissues. Deliverables include (1) the development of micro-fluidic systems and control systems capable of regulating complex 2D and 3D flow patterns, (2) a novel control algorithm design methodology for dealing with uncertain dynamics, and (3) fluorescent biosensor tools for evaluating control over the microfluidic environment of embryonic tissues.

This project will provide tools for tissue engineers to precisely control chemical stimulation that may be useful for creating new tissues for long term future clinical application. The work will combine techniques that previously have been successfully implemented in microfabrication and automatic control of disk drives. These tools may be used to create complex patterns of chemical stimulation to growing cells for manufacturing of engineered tissues. Dissemination of our results will also lead to new devices with increased accuracies, reliability, and functionality for commercial and basic science applications. In addition, this project will train undergraduate and graduate students to become leaders in science and industry in transdisciplinary fields including dynamic systems/controls, biology, microtechnology, and engineering. The team will also reach out to underrepresented K-12 students in academically challenged neighborhoods to build their knowledge and their interest in STEM.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research for this project came at an important time, as medical research is essential to an aging population in the United States. The responses of developmental biology systems are very related to aging as well as in birth defects. While traditional approaches are making some progress, addressing these challenges with logical yet novel ideas may lead to significant insights for their treatment in the future. One goal has been and continues to be to potentially commercialize some of these technologies in markets such as drug discovery and tissue engineering.  Furthermore, by providing fundamental understanding, this research was targeted to ensure the successful implementation of these ideas in academia, government, and industry.

 

The intellectual merit was the construction and control of a dynamic microfluidic system to probe the response of tissues to long term stimulation in developmental biology studies for areas like aging. Unlike previous work using microfluidics, in microfluidic networks large enough to accommodate larger scale tissues, the interfaces between the coflowing streams exhibited complex shape shapes even though the flows were still laminar. This required a system capable of controlling interface shape and as well its position. In addition, the nonlinear dynamics of this instrument provided the opportunity to apply a frequency response-based robust control design approach. This approach was distinct from other robust control methods in that the nominal model, performance weighting function, and bound on uncertainty needed only be functions of frequency. This project provided a unique controls-based approach to probe the role of chemical stimuli in development as organisms use pre-patterning, gene regulatory networks, and input from external stimulus to guide development. Our approach required the perspectives and skills from our team, which was uniquely qualified for this work by its diverse strengths in engineering, chemistry, physics, and cellular and molecular biology.

 

This broader impact interdisciplinary approach was generating great interest amongst researchers working in a wide variety of settings, including government, industry and universities.  The principal investigator envisioned that this broad level of interest led to the progressive development of interconnected training opportunities benefiting individuals from different educational levels and perspectives, including underrepresented and minority groups. One goal was to build an education and training pipeline for future leaders in engineering and science by working with K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows. These efforts included Pittsburgh’s Lincoln Technology Academy, serving one of the most academically challenged neighborhoods in Pennsylvania. We also worked through our appointment in the Sloan Foundation Minority PhD program to build our diversity efforts. Personnel development and research results significantly impacted fields including dynamic systems/controls, biology, microtechnology, and engineering. The results will be useful in developing clinical treatments along with the longer term impact of giving tools to the emerging field of synthetic biology for spatial and temporal control over complex multicellular arrays for applications in tissue engineering and biosynthesis.

 

The results from our research over this grant have been presented in a large number of peer-reviewed archival journal publications, and have provided support for multiple students. The work has also been presented at a variety of conferences including the American Society of Mechanical Engineers International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition and the Biomedical Engineering Society. Graduate students involved in this project developed a combined mechanics, chemistry, bi...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research for this project came at an important time, as medical research is essential to an aging population in the United States. The responses of developmental biology systems are very related to aging as well as in birth defects. While traditional approaches are making some progress, addressing these challenges with logical yet novel ideas may lead to significant insights for their treatment in the future. One goal has been and continues to be to potentially commercialize some of these technologies in markets such as drug discovery and tissue engineering. Furthermore, by providing fundamental understanding, this research was targeted to ensure the successful implementation of these ideas in academia, government, and industry. The intellectual merit was the construction and control of a dynamic microfluidic system to probe the response of tissues to long term stimulation in developmental biology studies for areas like aging. Unlike previous work using microfluidics, in microfluidic networks large enough to accommodate larger scale tissues, the interfaces between the coflowing streams exhibited complex shape shapes even though the flows were still laminar. This required a system capable of controlling interface shape and as well its position. In addition, the nonlinear dynamics of this instrument provided the opportunity to apply a frequency response-based robust control design approach. This approach was distinct from other robust control methods in that the nominal model, performance weighting function, and bound on uncertainty needed only be functions of frequency. This project provided a unique controls-based approach to probe the role of chemical stimuli in development as organisms use pre-patterning, gene regulatory networks, and input from external stimulus to guide development. Our approach required the perspectives and skills from our team, which was uniquely qualified for this work by its diverse strengths in engineering, chemistry, physics, and cellular and molecular biology. This broader impact interdisciplinary approach was generating great interest amongst researchers working in a wide variety of settings, including government, industry and universities. The principal investigator envisioned that this broad level of interest led to the progressive development of interconnected training opportunities benefiting individuals from different educational levels and perspectives, including underrepresented and minority groups. One goal was to build an education and training pipeline for future leaders in engineering and science by working with K-12 students, undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows. These efforts included PittsburghÆs Lincoln Technology Academy, serving one of the most academically challenged neighborhoods in Pennsylvania. We also worked through our appointment in the Sloan Foundation Minority PhD program to build our diversity efforts. Personnel development and research results significantly impacted fields including dynamic systems/controls, biology, microtechnology, and engineering. The results will be useful in developing clinical treatments along with the longer term impact of giving tools to the emerging field of synthetic biology for spatial and temporal control over complex multicellular arrays for applications in tissue engineering and biosynthesis. The results from our research over this grant have been presented in a large number of peer-reviewed archival journal publications, and have provided support for multiple students. The work has also been presented at a variety of conferences including the American Society of Mechanical Engineers International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition and the Biomedical Engineering Society. Graduate students involved in this project developed a combined mechanics, chemistry, biology, and material science background that have made them highly valuable in industry and academics.
